trans-unit.source: How to start an embedded server from an application

seg-source.mrk: How to start an embedded server from an application

target.mrk: How to start an embedded server from an application

trans-unit.source: In one thread, the embedding application starts the local JDBC driver for its own access.

seg-source.mrk: In one thread, the embedding application starts the local JDBC driver for its own access.

target.mrk: In one thread, the embedding application starts the local JDBC driver for its own access.

trans-unit.source: /* If you are running on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to invoke Class.forName(). In that environment, the EmbeddedDriver loads automatically. */ Class.forName("org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver"); Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection( "jdbc:derby:sample");

seg-source.mrk: /* If you are running on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to invoke Class.forName().
In that environment, the EmbeddedDriver loads automatically.

target.mrk: /* If you are running on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to invoke Class.forName().
In that environment, the EmbeddedDriver loads automatically.

trans-unit.source: In another thread, the same application starts the server framework to allow remote access. Starting the server framework from within the application allows both the server and the application to run in the same JVM.

seg-source.mrk: In another thread, the same application starts the server framework to allow remote access.
Starting the server framework from within the application allows both the server and the application to run in the same JVM.

target.mrk: In another thread, the same application starts the server framework to allow remote access.
Starting the server framework from within the application allows both the server and the application to run in the same JVM.
